title: 113_s1126
content: The "Prescribe A Book Act" establishes Pediatric Early Literacy Programs under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. It includes definitions for pediatric involvement in reading and education. The "Prescribe A Book Act" defines an eligible entity as a nonprofit organization with proven effectiveness in providing peer-to-peer training on literacy promotion to healthcare providers and delivering training through various medical education settings. The "Prescribe A Book Act" outlines key activities for eligible entities, including delivering training in medical education settings, providing technical assistance for implementing a Pediatric Early Literacy Program, offering discounted books to healthcare facilities, and integrating developmental research. The "Prescribe A Book Act" includes offering discounted books to healthcare facilities and integrating developmental research into training for healthcare providers. It also defines the Pediatric Early Literacy Program as a 3-part model implemented by healthcare providers. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program involves healthcare providers encouraging parents to read aloud to their children using research-based methods and offering recommendations for reading aloud. The Pediatric Early Literacy Program encourages parents to read aloud to their young children and provides developmentally appropriate recommendations. Healthcare providers give children aged 6 months to 5 years a new book at health visits. Volunteers in waiting areas also support literacy efforts. The program provides children aged 6 months to 5 years with a new book to take home and encourages parents to read aloud. Volunteers in healthcare facilities read aloud to children, promoting shared reading experiences. Research shows positive effects on parent behavior and children's language skills. The program promotes shared reading experiences by providing children with books and encouraging parents to read aloud. Research demonstrates effectiveness in improving parent behavior and children's language skills, endorsed by medical associations. The Secretary can award grants to eligible entities for Pediatric Early Literacy Programs. Eligible entities must submit an application with required information. Matching requirement is also specified. "Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant under section 5622. The entity receiving the grant must provide non-Federal matching funds equal to at least 50% of the grant received. These funds can be in cash or in-kind." An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 5622 must enter into contracts with private nonprofit organizations or public agencies to establish and operate a Pediatric Early Literacy Program. The entity must also provide training and technical assistance to contractors and include additional terms as determined by the Secretary. Each contractor selected by the eligible entity must prioritize serving at-risk children, including those from families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line. The Secretary may include additional terms in the agreement to ensure program effectiveness. The program gives priority to serving at-risk children, including those from families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line, children without adequate medical insurance, children enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, and children living in rural areas. Children eligible for the program include those from families with incomes below 200 percent of the poverty line, without adequate medical insurance, enrolled in Medicaid or CHIP, living in rural areas, migrant children, and those with limited access to libraries. The Secretary must ensure that eligible entities have arrangements with book publishers or distributors to obtain books at favorable discounts before making any payments under this subpart. Additionally, there is a reporting requirement outlined in Section 5627. The reporting requirement in Section 5627 mandates eligible entities to report annually on program effectiveness and descriptions of programs. A conforming amendment adds a new section for pediatric early literacy programs in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. A new section for pediatric early literacy programs is added to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, including definitions, program authorization, applications, matching requirements, use of grant funds, restrictions on payments, and reporting requirements.
